headline: Defense Stocks Jump After Trump Calls for $1.5 Trillion Defense Budget
summary: U.S. defense companies rallied premarket after President Trump called for a $1.5 trillion defense budget, more than $500 billion more than the Pentagon is expected to receive this fiscal year.  Trump said the increased budget was necessary “especially in these very troubled and dangerous times,” in a social-media post late Wednesday.  Shares of Northrop Grumman, Lockheed Martin, and RTX each jumped 4.5% or more in premarket trading.

content.title: Defense Stocks Jump After Trump Calls for $1.5 Trillion Defense Budget
content.summary: U.S. defense companies rallied premarket after President Trump called for a $1.5 trillion defense budget, more than $500 billion more than the Pentagon is expected to receive this fiscal year.  Trump said the increased budget was necessary “especially in these very troubled and dangerous times,” in a social-media post late Wednesday.  Shares of Northrop Grumman, Lockheed Martin, and RTX each jumped 4.5% or more in premarket trading.

headline: Trump Demands More Defense Spending But Threatens Biggest Contractors
summary: The apparently contradictory string of announcements sent shares of major defense contractors tumbling as traders sought to interpret the White House’s intentions — and whether they would ever come to pass.  It all began with a demand that hit on a long-time issue for Trump: Major defense contractors that work with the government must end stock buybacks, stop issuing dividends and cap executive pay at $5 million a year until they invest more in factories and research to speed development.  Hours later, Trump signed an executive order codifying the decision.

content.title: Trump Demands More Defense Spending But Threatens Biggest Contractors
content.summary: The apparently contradictory string of announcements sent shares of major defense contractors tumbling as traders sought to interpret the White House’s intentions — and whether they would ever come to pass.  It all began with a demand that hit on a long-time issue for Trump: Major defense contractors that work with the government must end stock buybacks, stop issuing dividends and cap executive pay at $5 million a year until they invest more in factories and research to speed development.  Hours later, Trump signed an executive order codifying the decision.

headline: US markets lower before the bell after hot start to the year
summary: U.S. markets are pointing lower before the opening bell as the optimism that seemed kicked off the new year fades. Futures for the S&P 500 declined 0.2% Thursday, while Dow Jones Industrial Average futures lost 0.4%. Nasdaq futures were off 0.3% before the bell.

content.title: US markets lower before the bell after hot start to the year
content.summary: U.S. markets are pointing lower before the opening bell as the optimism that seemed kicked off the new year fades. Futures for the S&P 500 declined 0.2% Thursday, while Dow Jones Industrial Average futures lost 0.4%. Nasdaq futures were off 0.3% before the bell.

summary: U.S. defense companies rallied premarket after President Trump called for a $1.5 trillion defense budget, more than $500 billion more than the Pentagon is expected to receive this fiscal year.  Trump said the increased budget was necessary “especially in these very troubled and dangerous times,” in a social-media post late Wednesday.  Shares of Northrop Grumman, Lockheed Martin, L3Harris and RTX jumped between 3% and 8%.

headline: Defense Stocks Soar Again as Trump Plans Military Budget Boost
summary: A Goldman Sachs Group Inc. basket of European defense stocks rose as much as 3.8% on Thursday, extending its gain for the week to about 13%.  In the US, Northrop Grumman Corp. and Lockheed Martin Corp. surged more than 6% in premarket trading, rebounding from a drop the previous day when Trump called for curbs on executive pay and shareholder returns in the sector.  Defense stocks also rose in Asia.

content.title: Defense Stocks Soar Again as Trump Plans Military Budget Boost
content.summary: A Goldman Sachs Group Inc. basket of European defense stocks rose as much as 3.8% on Thursday, extending its gain for the week to about 13%.  In the US, Northrop Grumman Corp. and Lockheed Martin Corp. surged more than 6% in premarket trading, rebounding from a drop the previous day when Trump called for curbs on executive pay and shareholder returns in the sector.  Defense stocks also rose in Asia.

headline: Defense Stocks Surge as Trump Floats Pentagon Budget Boost
summary: In the US, Northrop Grumman Corp. and Lockheed Martin Corp. surged at least 9.3% before paring some gains, rebounding from Wednesday’s drop sparked by Trump’s demands to limit executive pay and shareholder returns.  A Goldman Sachs Group Inc. basket of European defense stocks rose as much as 3.8% Thursday, extending its gain for the week to about 15%.  The rally comes after Trump demanded a $500 billion increase in annual defense spending to $1.5 trillion, which would require Congressional approval.

content.title: Defense Stocks Surge as Trump Floats Pentagon Budget Boost
content.summary: In the US, Northrop Grumman Corp. and Lockheed Martin Corp. surged at least 9.3% before paring some gains, rebounding from Wednesday’s drop sparked by Trump’s demands to limit executive pay and shareholder returns.  A Goldman Sachs Group Inc. basket of European defense stocks rose as much as 3.8% Thursday, extending its gain for the week to about 15%.  The rally comes after Trump demanded a $500 billion increase in annual defense spending to $1.5 trillion, which would require Congressional approval.

headline: How Trump shook up defense stocks this week
summary: President Donald Trump caused some commotion for investors in U.S. defense contractors this week.  First, Trump criticized the companies for taking too long to produce military equipment and also failing to maintain it while at the same time paying out billions in dividends and stock buybacks to investors.  Shares of Lockheed Martin, General Dynamics, Northrop Grumman and Raytheon parent RTX fell after the criticism but then roared back at the prospect of more lucrative government contracts down the road.

content.title: How Trump shook up defense stocks this week
content.summary: President Donald Trump caused some commotion for investors in U.S. defense contractors this week.  First, Trump criticized the companies for taking too long to produce military equipment and also failing to maintain it while at the same time paying out billions in dividends and stock buybacks to investors.  Shares of Lockheed Martin, General Dynamics, Northrop Grumman and Raytheon parent RTX fell after the criticism but then roared back at the prospect of more lucrative government contracts down the road.

headline: Trump's proposed $1.5 trillion defense budget sends military contractor shares soaring
summary: President Donald Trump caused some commotion for investors in U.S. defense contractors this week.  First, Trump criticized the companies for taking too long to produce military equipment and also failing to maintain it while at the same time paying out billions in dividends and stock buybacks to investors.  Shares of Lockheed Martin, General Dynamics, Northrop Grumman and Raytheon parent RTX fell after the criticism but then roared back at the prospect of more lucrative government contracts down the road.

content.title: Trump's proposed $1.5 trillion defense budget sends military contractor shares soaring
content.summary: President Donald Trump caused some commotion for investors in U.S. defense contractors this week.  First, Trump criticized the companies for taking too long to produce military equipment and also failing to maintain it while at the same time paying out billions in dividends and stock buybacks to investors.  Shares of Lockheed Martin, General Dynamics, Northrop Grumman and Raytheon parent RTX fell after the criticism but then roared back at the prospect of more lucrative government contracts down the road.

thumbnail.caption: Trader John Mauro works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, Thursday, Jan. 8, 2026. (AP Photo/Richard Drew)

headline: Defense Stocks Move Higher After Trump Calls for Huge Defense Budget
summary: U.S. defense companies rallied after President Trump called for a $1.5 trillion defense budget, more than $500 billion more than the Pentagon is expected to receive this fiscal year.  Trump said the increased budget was necessary “especially in these very troubled and dangerous times,” in a social-media post late Wednesday.  Shares of Northrop Grumman, Lockheed Martin and L3Harris jumped between 2.5% and 5%.

content.title: Defense Stocks Move Higher After Trump Calls for Huge Defense Budget
content.summary: U.S. defense companies rallied after President Trump called for a $1.5 trillion defense budget, more than $500 billion more than the Pentagon is expected to receive this fiscal year.  Trump said the increased budget was necessary “especially in these very troubled and dangerous times,” in a social-media post late Wednesday.  Shares of Northrop Grumman, Lockheed Martin and L3Harris jumped between 2.5% and 5%.

headline: How major US stock indexes fared Thursday, 1/8/2026
summary: Modest moves for Wall Street overall masked big gains underneath the surface, including for makers of weapons and other military equipment. The S&P 500 closed barely changed Thursday, coming off its first loss in four days. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.6%, and the Nasdaq composite fell 0.4%.

headline: Defense Stock Rally Extends Into 2026 as Geopolitics Stays Tense
summary: Contractors L3Harris Technologies Inc. and Huntington Ingalls Industries Inc. have each advanced 11% across the first five trading days of 2026, buoyed in part by a rally following the US military operation that removed Venezuela’s Nicolas Maduro from power.  Major peers such as Northrop Grumman Corp. have risen 4% or more, while drone maker AeroVironment Inc. has jumped 40%.

content.summary: Contractors L3Harris Technologies Inc. and Huntington Ingalls Industries Inc. have each advanced 11% across the first five trading days of 2026, buoyed in part by a rally following the US military operation that removed Venezuela’s Nicolas Maduro from power.  Major peers such as Northrop Grumman Corp. have risen 4% or more, while drone maker AeroVironment Inc. has jumped 40%.

headline: Most of Wall Street drifts as defense companies rally
summary: Modest moves for Wall Street overall masked some big swings underneath the surface on Thursday, including for makers of weapons and other military equipment after President Donald Trump  said he wants to increase spending on them sharply.  The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 270 points, or 0.6%, and the Nasdaq composite fell 0.4%.  The majority of stocks climbed as yields ticked higher in the bond market following mixed reports on the U.S. economy.

content.title: Most of Wall Street drifts as defense companies rally
content.summary: Modest moves for Wall Street overall masked some big swings underneath the surface on Thursday, including for makers of weapons and other military equipment after President Donald Trump  said he wants to increase spending on them sharply.  The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 270 points, or 0.6%, and the Nasdaq composite fell 0.4%.  The majority of stocks climbed as yields ticked higher in the bond market following mixed reports on the U.S. economy.

thumbnail.caption: Specialist James Denaro works at his post on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, Thursday, Jan. 8, 2026. (AP Photo/Richard Drew)

headline: Trump's defense spending plans send 'strong' demand signal
summary: President Trump made waves in the defense industry on Thursday after stating via social media that he wants to raise 2027's military spending budget to $1.5 trillion while pushing for a cap on defense CEO pay packages. Gabelli Funds portfolio manager Tony Bancroft discusses what Trump's comments on production signal about defense demand amid various ongoing geopolitical conflicts, such as Ukraine's war with Russia and the recent US invasion of Venezuela. Bancroft manages the Gabelli Commercial Aerospace and Defense ETF (GCAD). To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination Overtime.

content.title: Trump's defense spending plans send 'strong' demand signal
content.description:
President Trump made waves in the defense industry on Thursday after stating via social media that he wants to raise 2027's military spending budget to $1.5 trillion while pushing for a cap on defense CEO pay packages.

Gabelli Funds portfolio manager Tony Bancroft discusses what Trump's comments on production signal about defense demand amid various ongoing geopolitical conflicts, such as Ukraine's war with Russia and the recent US invasion of Venezuela.

Bancroft manages the Gabelli Commercial Aerospace and Defense ETF (GCAD).

To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination Overtime.

headline: Trump's plans for Venezuelan oil, defense spending hikes
summary: President Trump is giving Wall Street investors whiplash with a deluge of new policy proposals, from hiking defense spending to $1.5 trillion to expecting 50 million barrels of Venezuelan oil (CL=F, BZ=F) and plans to ban institutional investors from buying single-family homes. Yahoo Finance Washington correspondent Ben Werschkul comes on the program to explain Trump's vision for the US occupation of Venezuela in relation to the oil industry, while the administration seeks to raise its defense budget in 2027. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief.

headline: Defense Stock Rally Extends as Geopolitics Stays Tense
summary: Contractors L3Harris Technologies Inc. and Huntington Ingalls Industries Inc. have advanced 11% across the first five trading days of 2026, buoyed in part by a rally following the US military operation that removed Venezuela’s Nicolas Maduro from power.  Major peers such as Northrop Grumman Corp. and Lockheed Martin Corp. have risen about 4% or more, while drone maker AeroVironment Inc. has jumped over 40%.

headline: Lockheed Martin, Northrop, RTX: Why defense stocks are climbing
summary: Defense stocks, like Northrop Grumman (NOC), Lockheed Martin (LMT), and RTX (RTX), are on the rise after President Trump proposed a plan to raise the US defense spending budget from $1 trillion to $1.5 trillion for 2027. Yahoo Finance Senior Reporter Brooke DiPalma chats with Julie Hyman on Opening Bid to examine the recent stock moves and explain what's next for the defense sector. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Opening Bid.

Defense stocks, like Northrop Grumman (NOC), Lockheed Martin (LMT), and RTX (RTX), are on the rise after President Trump proposed a plan to raise the US defense spending budget from $1 trillion to $1.5 trillion for 2027.

Yahoo Finance Senior Reporter Brooke DiPalma chats with Julie Hyman on Opening Bid to examine the recent stock moves and explain what's next for the defense sector.

To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Opening Bid.
